initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories: The US State Department has issued a statement urging Russia to release Sgt Black and provide him with fair treatment, saying that the US is "deeply concerned" about his detention. The department also reiterated its calls for the release of the two other American citizens being held in Russia, Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan.

The statement comes as tensions between the US and Russia continue to escalate over the war in Ukraine, with the US imposing new sanctions on Russia and Russia retaliating by expelling several US diplomats. The US has also accused Russia of violating the terms of a 2010 arms control treaty, and has threatened to withdraw from the treaty if Russia does not comply.

The US has also accused Russia of interfering in the 2020 US presidential election, and has imposed sanctions on several Russian individuals and entities accused of election meddling. The situation has raised concerns about the potential for a wider conflict between the two nations, and has led to calls for increased diplomacy and dialogue to resolve the crisis.

The US and Russia have a long history of tensions, dating back to the Cold War era, and the current situation is a reminder of the need for continued dialogue and cooperation to prevent further escalation.

However, despite the efforts of diplomats and world leaders, the situation remains precarious, with both sides engaging in a war of words and escalating military posturing, leaving many to wonder if the world is on the brink of a new era of conflict.

As tensions continue to rise, the international community is bracing for the worst, with many experts warning of a potential catastrophic outcome if the situation is not defused. Meanwhile, the economic implications of the crisis are already being felt, with global markets experiencing a significant downturn and trade relations between the two nations reaching a standstill.

The United Nations Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting to discuss the escalating crisis, with diplomats from around the world scrambling to find a solution to the impasse. In the meantime, citizens of both nations are growing increasingly anxious, with many taking to the streets to protest the escalating tensions and demand a peaceful resolution.

As the meeting gets underway, tensions are running high, with both sides refusing to budge on their demands. The US Secretary of State is urging calm, but the Russian Foreign Minister is warning of "grave consequences" if the sanctions are not lifted. Meanwhile, protesters in major cities around the world are calling for their governments to take a stronger stance against the escalating crisis.

The streets are filled with chants of "No to sanctions!" and "Stand with Russia!" as the crowd grows more restless, with some protesters clashing with police in a few instances. Back in the meeting room, the US Secretary of State is trying to reason with the Russian Foreign Minister, but the atmosphere remains tense, with both sides dug in and refusing to compromise.

The Russian Foreign Minister's face is red with anger as he slams his fist on the table, his voice rising in defiance. "We will not be bullied by your threats and sanctions, Secretary," he growls. "Russia will not be pushed around by the United States." The Secretary of State's expression remains calm, but her eyes flash with frustration. "We're not trying to bully you, Minister," she says. "We're trying to protect our national interests and the stability of the global economy. Your actions are causing harm to innocent people and destabilizing the region."

The Russian Foreign Minister's face twists in a scowl, his eyes narrowing. "You're not trying to protect your interests, Secretary? You're trying to impose your will on us, to dictate how we run our country. Well, I can tell you that won't happen. We will not be dictated to by the United States or any other country." The Secretary of State's calm demeanor begins to crack, her voice taking on a slightly sharper tone. "Minister, we're not trying to dictate to you. We're trying to work with you to find a solution that benefits everyone. But your actions are making it difficult for us to do that."

"I'm not sure what you're talking about, Secretary," the Russian Foreign Minister sneers. "We're simply exercising our sovereign right to defend our interests. You're the ones who are being aggressive, with your sanctions and your military build-up along our borders. You're trying to intimidate us, to make us back down. Well, I can tell you that won't work. We will not be intimidated by the United States."

"The United States is not trying to intimidate you, Minister," the Secretary of State responds calmly. "We're simply trying to protect our own interests and those of our allies. Your actions in Ukraine and your support for terrorist groups in the Middle East are a threat to global stability. We're not going to stand idly by while you continue to destabilize the region. We're willing to negotiate and find a peaceful resolution, but we will not be deterred from defending our interests."

"The United States is not the only one concerned about global stability, Secretary," the Minister retorts, his voice firm but controlled. "We have our own interests and security concerns that must be taken into account. Your accusations about Ukraine are baseless and your claims about terrorist groups are unfounded. We will not be bullied or threatened by the United States or any other country. We are willing to negotiate, but we will not be pushed around or forced to compromise our sovereignty."

"The United States is not trying to bully or threaten you, Minister," the Secretary responds, her tone calm and measured. "We are simply trying to address the growing concerns about the spread of terrorism and the destabilization of the region. We have evidence that suggests Ukraine is not as innocent as you claim, and we will not back down from our position. We are willing to work with you to find a solution, but we will not compromise on our values and principles. We expect you to do the same."

"I understand your concerns, Secretary, but I must remind you that Ukraine is a sovereign nation and we will not be lectured on our internal affairs. The evidence you speak of is likely fabricated and we will not be swayed by baseless accusations. We are willing to work with you, but we will not be bullied or coerced into compromising our values and principles. We expect you to respect our sovereignty and our right to self-determination."

"We have made it clear to you, Secretary, that we are willing to engage in constructive dialogue and cooperation, but only on the basis of mutual respect and equality. We will not be intimidated or pressured into making concessions that compromise our national interests or values. We expect a more constructive and respectful approach from your government, and we hope that we can work together to find solutions that benefit both our nations."

"We believe that a spirit of cooperation and mutual understanding is essential for addressing the complex challenges we face, and we are willing to work together to find common ground and achieve shared goals. However, we must emphasize that our national interests and values are non-negotiable, and we will not compromise on issues that are fundamental to our sovereignty and identity. We hope that your government will join us in this spirit of cooperation and mutual respect, and that together we can build a brighter future for our nations and the world."

"We are committed to upholding the principles of democracy, human rights, and the rule of law, and we expect the same from our partners. We believe that a strong and stable international order is essential for promoting peace, stability, and prosperity, and we are willing to work together to strengthen it. We also recognize that our nations have different histories, cultures, and perspectives, and we are committed to respecting and celebrating these differences. We look forward to a productive and constructive dialogue, and we are confident that together we can achieve great things."

"We are excited to announce that we will be hosting a series of high-level meetings and workshops to discuss key issues and challenges facing our nations, including economic development, climate change, and global health. We believe that by working together, we can find innovative solutions to these complex problems and make a positive impact on the world. We also look forward to exploring new opportunities for cooperation and collaboration, and to deepening our understanding of each other's priorities and concerns."

"The meetings will take place over the course of three days, from March 15th to 17th, at the United Nations headquarters in New York City. We have invited a diverse range of experts and stakeholders to join us, including government officials, business leaders, academics, and civil society representatives. We are confident that this gathering will be a valuable opportunity for us to share knowledge, exchange ideas, and build consensus on the most pressing issues of our time."

"The agenda is packed with thought-provoking sessions, including keynote addresses, panel discussions, and working group meetings. We will be tackling topics such as climate change, sustainable development, and global economic inequality, among others. We are also planning a special ceremony to honor the contributions of individuals and organizations working towards a more just and equitable world. We look forward to seeing you there and working together to shape a brighter future for all."

"The event will take place on March 15th and 16th at the United Nations Headquarters in New York City. Registration is now open, and we encourage you to reserve your spot as soon as possible, as space is limited. A special discount is available for students and non-profit organizations. We are also offering a limited number of scholarships for individuals from developing countries. For more information, please visit our website or contact us at [info@globalsummit.org](mailto:info@globalsummit.org)."
